pullRequest.body:
Add attribute `elab_as_elim` to binary recursors. Also add `inline` and `specialize` for performance.

Without `specialize`, the `popcountTR` in the test is not tail-recursive, and so crashes with
```
error: libc++abi: terminating due to uncaught exception of type lean::throwable: deep recursion was detected at 'interpreter' 
```

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#15571~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
Please explain the motivation in the PR description.

> Also add `inline` and `specialize` for performance.

Was this measurable, or speculative? If you measured it, can you include a comparison of before / after?

I can't give a measurement right away, but you can find a lot of similar usage in some data structure APIs in `Batteries`. IIRC applications like #17892 need `specialize` for tail recursion optimization.

> IIRC applications like #17892 need `specialize` for tail recursion optimization.

This should be easy enough to test, right? I think you could test this by:
* writing a function a function that counts the number of set bits (in a `tests/` file)
* checking it can be evaluated on `2^2024`, which is larger than the default stack depth of 1000
* checking (but not committing) that it didn't work without `specialize`.
There is no additional stack depth limit for runtime. But it's ok to make a test.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11409567578/job/31750064019)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11409567578/job/31750063635)

bors merge

Thanks!

bors merge

Thanks!
What happened here?
`rw [size]` only unfolds `Nat.size` on the left side after this PR. I don't know why.
Thanks, this does indeed crash without the `specialize`!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(Data/Nat/Bits): attribute `elab_as_elim` `inline` `specialize`

Please explain the motivation in the PR description.

> Also add `inline` and `specialize` for performance.

Was this measurable, or speculative? If you measured it, can you include a comparison of before / after?

I can't give a measurement right away, but you can find a lot of similar usage in some data structure APIs in `Batteries`. IIRC applications like #17892 need `specialize` for tail recursion optimization.

> IIRC applications like #17892 need `specialize` for tail recursion optimization.

This should be easy enough to test, right? I think you could test this by:
* writing a function a function that counts the number of set bits (in a `tests/` file)
* checking it can be evaluated on `2^2024`, which is larger than the default stack depth of 1000
* checking (but not committing) that it didn't work without `specialize`.
There is no additional stack depth limit for runtime. But it's ok to make a test.
